case_name: Durgah Committee and Nazim v. Khadims of the tomb of Khwaja Moinud-din Chishti

facts.text: Civil Appeal No. 272 of 1960 filed in Supreme Court.

anchor.surface_text: CIVIL APPELLATE JURISDICTION Civil Appeal No. 272 of 1960. Appeal from the judgment and order dated January

facts.text: Appeal from Rajasthan High Court judgment and order dated January 28, 1959 in D.B. Civil Writ Petition No. 17 of 1957.

anchor.surface_text: Appeal from the judgment and order dated January 28, 1959, of the Rajasthan High Court in D. B. Civil Writ. Petition No. 17 of 1957. N. Sanyal,, Additional Solicitor-

facts.text: Nine respondents, Khadims of the tomb of Khwaja Moinud-din Chishti of Ajmer, filed writ petition under Art. 226 challenging vires of Durgah Khwaja Saheb Act XXXVI of 1955.

anchor.surface_text: In.the High Court of Judicature for Rajasthan at Jodhpur a writ petition was filed under Art. 226 of the Constitution by the nine respondents who are Khadims of the tomb of Khwaja Moinud-din Chishti of Ajmer challenging the vires of the Durgah Khwaja Saheb Act XXXVI of 1955  hereafter called the Act .

facts.text: High Court declared impugned provisions of the Act ultra vires and restrained appellants from enforcing them.

anchor.surface_text: The writ petition thus filed by the respondents substantially succeeded and the High Court has made a declaration that the impugned provisions of the Act are ultra vires and has issued an order restraining the appellants from enforcing them.

facts.text: Appellants obtained certificate from High Court and appealed to Supreme Court.

anchor.surface_text: The appellants then applied for and obtained a certificate from the High Court and it is with the said certificate that they have companye to this Court by their present appeal.

facts.text: Shrine of Khwaja Moin-ud-din Chishti at Ajmer is important pilgrimage site for Muslims and non-Muslims.

anchor.surface_text: According to the respondents the shrine of Nazrat Khwaja Moin-ud-din Chishti which is generally known as the Durgah Khwaja Saheb situated at Ajmer is one of the most important places of pilgrimage for the muslims of India. Since persons following other religious also hold the saint in great veneration a large number of number-muslims visit the tomb every year.

facts.text: Khwaja Moin-ud-din Chishti died in or about 1236 A.D.

anchor.surface_text: He died at Ajmer in or about 1236 D., and naturally enough after his death-his tomb became a place of pilgrimage.

facts.text: Khadims are descendants of Khwaja Syed Fukhuruddin and Sheikh Mohammad Yadgar, who looked after the grave after saint's death.

anchor.surface_text: Khwaja Syed Fukhuruddin and Sheikh Mohammad Yadgar, who originally accompanied the Khwaja Saheb Syed to India, were his close and devoted followers. After the saints death both of them looked after the, grave and attended to the spiritual needs of the pilgrims. The descendants of these two disciples gradually came to be known as Khadims.

facts.text: Khadims claim rights to offerings (Nazars) as their property, recognized by Privy Council in Syed Altaf Hussain v. Dewan Syed Ali Rasul Ali Khan.

anchor.surface_text: According to the respondents the right of the Khadims to the offerings and Nazars made by pilgrims before the tomb and at the Durgah had been the subject matter of several judicial decisions and the same had been finally decided by the Privy Council in Syed Altaf Hussain v. Dewan Syed Ali Rasul Ali Khan

facts.text: Appellants deny Khadims' rights to offerings; claim Khadims are servants like chowkidars.

anchor.surface_text: According to the appellants the religious services at the tomb were and are performed by the Saiiadanashin of the Durgah and the respondents had numberright to look after the premises, to keep the keys of the tomb, to attend to the pilgrims visiting the shrine or to receive any offerings or Nazars. Their case was that the Khadims were and are numbermore, than servants of the holy tomb and their duties are similar to those of chowkidars.

facts.text: High Court found offerings made before tomb for nearly 400 years used by Khadims.

anchor.surface_text: The High Court has found that the offerings made before the tomb for nearly 400 years before the tomb was rebuilt into a pucca structure must have been used by the Khadims for themselves.

facts.text: Privy Council decision in Asrar Ahmed v. Durgah Committee, Ajmer (AIR 1947 PC 1) held Mutawalli office is State appointment.

anchor.surface_text: the decision of the Privy Council in Asrar Ahmed v. Durgah Commitee, Ajmer  2 .

facts.text: Khwaja Moin-ud-din born in 1143 in Persia.

anchor.surface_text: Khwaja Moin-ud-din was born in Persia in 1143.

facts.text: Akbar granted 18 villages to Durgah around 1567-1575 A.D. for langar khana.

anchor.surface_text: A Farman issued by Akhar ascribed to the year 1567 shows that eighteen villages were granted to the Durgah. According to the report of the Committee which had access to the original Sanad and other relevant documents the year of the Sanad was number 1567 but 1575.

facts.text: Shahjehan separated office of Sajjadanashin from Mutawalli (Darogah).

anchor.surface_text: During Shahjehans time  1627-1658  some significant changes took place in the management of the Durgah. ,The office of the Sajjadanashin was separated from that of the Mutawalli under the name of Darogah, the Mutawalli was put in charge of the management and administration of the secular affairs of the Durgah.

facts.text: Act XX of 1863 transferred management of religious endowments from Revenue Boards to trustees.

anchor.surface_text: The first Act to which reference must be made is Act XX of 1863. This Act was passed to enable the Government to divest itself of the management of religious endowments which had till then vested in the Revenue Boards.

facts.text: Durgah Khwaja Saheb Act XXIII of 1936 enacted for administration of Durgah.

anchor.surface_text: In 1936 Act XXIII of 1936 was passed specifically with the object of making better provision for the administration of the Durgah and the Endowment of the Durgah of Khwaja Moin-ud-din Chishti known as the Durgah Khwaja Saheb, Ajmer.

facts.text: Ghulam Hasan Committee appointed in 1949, reported October 13, 1949.

anchor.surface_text: As we have already indicated the Government of India appointed the Committee under the Chairmanship of Mr. Justice Ghulam Hasan in 1949 to enquires into and report on the administration of the Durgah Endowment... The Committee made its report on October 13, 1949,

facts.text: Durgah Khwaja Saheb Act XXXVI of 1955 enacted based on Committee recommendations.

anchor.surface_text: that led to the promulgation of Ordinance No. XXIV of 1949 which was followed by Emergency Provisions Act, 1950, and finally by the Act of 1955 with which we are companycerned in the present appeal.

facts.text: Supreme Court judgment delivered March 17, 1961 by GAJENDRAGADKAR J.

anchor.surface_text: 1961. March 17. The Judjment of the Court was delivered by GAJENDRAGADKAR, J.-

facts.text: Supreme Court held Act constitutional, overturned High Court.

anchor.surface_text: a careful examination of the relevant sections in the light of the criticisms made by Mr. Pathak against them has satisfied us that numbere of the impugned sections can be said to be unconstitutional.

facts.text: Khadims perform daily religious duties at the tomb as per affidavit.

anchor.surface_text: According to this affidavit, every day one Khadim in rotation opens the first gate of the dome companytaining the shrine at 4 a. m. after pronouncing the sacred call named the Azan.

facts.text: Judicial Commissioner 1931 findings on division of offerings between Diwan, Khadims, Durgah Committee.

anchor.surface_text: The rights of the Diwan in respect of offerings made at the Durgah are declared to be as follows-- All offerings or presents made to the Diwan at the Diwans Khanqah or sitting place within the precincts of the Durgah are the exclusive property of the Diwan.

facts.text: Privy Council 1938 confirmed distinction between offerings for Durgah use and others divisible between Dewan and Khadims.

anchor.surface_text: the Privy Council observed that it was companyceded by the parties before the Court of Appeal that a distinction must be drawn inter alia between those articles such as Qaberposhes which are presented for the use of the Durgah and the, other offerings which are made at the Durgah

issues.text: Whether the material provisions of the Durgah Khwaja Saheb Act, 1955 violate the fundamental rights of the Khadims and the Chishtia Soofies under Articles 14, 19(1)(f) and (g), 25, 26, 31(1) and (2), and 32 of the Constitution?

anchor.surface_text: Thus the respondents challenged the vires of the Act on the ground that its material provisions take A.I.R. 1938 P.C. 71. away and or abridge their fundamental rights as a class and also the fundamental rights of the muslims belonging to the Soofi Chishtia Order guaranteed by Arts. 14, 19  1   f  and  g , 25, 26, 31 1  and  2  as well as 32.

issues.text: Whether section 5 of the Act, constituting the Durgah Committee of Hanafi Muslims not necessarily from the Chishtia Order, is inconsistent with Article 26?

anchor.surface_text: In regard to s. 5 of the Act under which the Durgah Committee is constituted the respondents objection is that it can consist of Hanafi muslims who are number members of the Chishtia Order and that introduces an infirmity which makes the said provision inconsistent with Art. 26 of the Constitution.

issues.text: Whether the Chishtia sect can be regarded as a religious denomination or a section thereof within Article 26?

anchor.surface_text: Such an enquiry would serve to assist us in determining whether the Chishtia sect can be regarded as a religious denomination or a section thereof within Art. 26.

issues.text: Whether the impugned provisions of the Act are inconsistent with Article 26(b), (c), (d)?

anchor.surface_text: The challenge to the vires of the Act rests broadly on two principal grounds. It is urged that its impugned provisions are inconsistent with Art. 26 b ,  c ,  d  of the Constitution and thereby violate the right to freedom of religion and to manage denominational institutions guaranteed by the said Article.

issues.text: Whether some provisions of the Act violate Article 19(1)(f) and (g)?

anchor.surface_text: It is also argued that some of its provisions are violative of the respondents fundamental right guaranteed under Art. 19 1  f  and  g . It would be convenient to deal with these two principal grounds of attack before examining the other arguments urged against the validity of different sections.
It has held that s. 2 b v violates Art. 19 1 f , s. 5 violates Art. 26, s. 11 f Arts. 19 1 g and 25 1 , ss. 11 b and 13 1 Art. 25, s. 14 Art. 19 1 f and as. 16 and 18 Art. 14 read with Art. 32.
s. 11 f Arts. 19 1 g and 25 1 , ss. 11 b and 13 1 Art. 25, s. 14 Art. 19 1 f and as. 16 and 18 Art. 14 read with Art. 32.
ss. 11 b and 13 1 Art. 25, s. 14 Art. 19 1 f and as. 16 and 18 Art. 14 read with Art. 32.
s. 14 Art. 19 1 f and as. 16 and 18 Art. 14 read with Art. 32.

issues.text: Whether sections 16 and 18 violate Article 14 read with Article 32?

anchor.surface_text: as. 16 and 18 Art. 14 read with Art. 32. Having found that these sections are ultra vires the High Court has issued an order restraining the appellants from enforcing the said sections.

anchor.surface_text: Thus the respondents challenged the vires of the Act on the ground that its material provisions take A.I.R. 1938 P.C. 71. away and or abridge their fundamental rights as a class and also the fundamental rights of the muslims belonging to the Soofi Chishtia Order guaranteed by Arts. 14, 19  1   f  and  g , 25, 26, 31 1  and  2  as well as 32.

arguments.court_reasoning: Careful examination shows none of the impugned sections unconstitutional; historical management by State, no pre-existing rights under Art 26.

holdings.text: We must, therefore, hold that the challenge to the vires of S. 5 and the subsidiary sections which deal with the powers of the Committee on the ground that the said provisions violate the fundamental right guaranteed to the denomination represented by the respondents under Art. 26 c and d fails.

anchor.surface_text: We must, therefore, hold that the challenge to the vires of S. 5 and the subsidiary sections which deal with the powers of the Committee on the ground that the said provisions violate the fundamental right guaranteed to the denomination represented by the respondents under Art. 26 c and d fails.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Historical evidence shows Durgah endowments always managed by State-appointed Mutawallis, not denomination; Art.26 protects only pre-existing rights.

holdings.text: the challenge to the vires of these two provisions must also fail.

anchor.surface_text: the challenge to the vires of these two provisions must also fail.

holdings.reasoning_summary: s.2(d)(v) and s.14 regulate only Durgah offerings (earmarked for institution), not Khadims' recognized rights to other offerings; consistent with prior judicial decisions.

holdings.text: the provisions of s. 11 f and h are valid and do not suffer from any constitutional infirmity.

anchor.surface_text: the provisions of s. 11 f and h are valid and do not suffer from any constitutional infirmity.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Regulate secular duties/privileges of Khadims and Sajjadanashin; must comply with s.15 (Muslim law); religious matters excluded or per s.16.

holdings.text: the provisions of s. 16 can be sustained on the ground that they are obviously in the interest of the institution as well as the parties concerned.

anchor.surface_text: the provisions of s. 16 can be sustained on the ground that they are obviously in the interest of the institution as well as the parties concerned.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Provides arbitration for secular disputes only; reasonable procedure, impartial; does not violate equality or access to courts for religious matters.

outcome.relief_summary: Impugned provisions of the Durgah Khwaja Saheb Act held constitutional; High Court declaration that sections are ultra vires set aside; writ petition dismissed

anchor.surface_text: We must, therefore, hold that the challenge to the vires of S. 5 and the subsidiary sections which deal with the powers of the Committee on the ground that the said provisions violate the fundamental right guaranteed to the denomination represented by the respondents under Art. 26 c and d fails.

has satisfied us that none of the impugned sections can be said to be unconstitutional. If as a result of the enforcement of the present Act incidentally more offerings are paid to the Durgah and are received on behalf of the Durgah that is a consequence which the respondents may regard as unfortunate but which introduces no infirmity in the validity of the Act.

for the purpose of the present appeal we propose to deal with the dispute between the parties on the basis that the Chishtia sect whom the respondents purport to represent ... is a section or a religious denomination.
the challenge to the vires of these two provisions must also fail.

has satisfied us that none of the impugned sections can be said to be unconstitutional. If as a result of the enforcement of the present Act incidentally more offerings are paid to the Durgah and are received on behalf of the Durgah that is a consequence which the respondents may regard as unfortunate but which introduces no infirmity in the validity of the Act.
the provisions of s. 11 f and h are valid and do not suffer from any constitutional infirmity.

the provisions of s. 16 can be sustained on the ground that they are obviously in the interest of the institution as well as the parties concerned.

has satisfied us that none of the impugned sections can be said to be unconstitutional. If as a result of the enforcement of the present Act incidentally more offerings are paid to the Durgah and are received on behalf of the Durgah that is a consequence which the respondents may regard as unfortunate but which introduces no infirmity in the validity of the Act.
it is futile to contend that s. 13(1) offends against Art. 25(1) of the Constitution.
